017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
020
021/**
022 * Trigonometric approximations for sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2(), with variants for most
023 * that allow users to trade speed for precision or vice versa. This is primarily derived from libGDX's MathUtils class.
024 * Unlike MathUtils, it exposes much more of its internal data, trusting that users can know what they are doing. A key
025 * difference here is that all methods have variants that treat angles as radians, as degrees, and as turns. That is,
026 * while a full rotation around a circle is {@code 2.0 * PI} radians, it is 360.0 degrees, and it is 1.0 turns.
027 * <br>
028 * This contains four fairly-sizeable lookup tables for some methods (in total RAM usage, just over 384KB); two store
029 * 16385 results of sin() (one as float, one as double) and the other two store 16385 results of cos() (as float and as
030 * double). Yes, I know they are the same data, just offset from each other or as a different type; some of the methods
031 * here run so briefly that getting the index with offset nearly doubled the time taken by the method. Here,
032 * {@link #sin(float)}, {@link #cos(float)}, and
033 * {@link #tan(float)} use the LUTs. Other methods here use techniques ranging from basic Taylor series to Pad√©
034 * approximants. The lookup-table-based sin() and cos() can be extraordinarily fast if the 64KB table can stay in a
035 * processor cache, while the "smooth" approximations may have decent quality but perform less quickly compared to an
036 * in-cache lookup table. Available now are "precise" versions of all methods here, such as
037 * {@link #sinPrecise(float)}. The "precise" versions all avoid a lookup table entirely and tend to
038 * be the most precise approximations here, while still outperforming {@link Math} versions of their function. In a few
039 * cases, the "precise" versions are also the fastest; this occurs most often for tan variants, or situations
040 * where a large lookup table is not possible for the processor to cache.
041 * <br>
042 * Relative to MathUtils in libGDX, the main new functionalities are the variants that take or
043 * return measurements in turns, the now-available {@link #SIN_TABLE}, and {@link #COS_TABLE}.
044 * Using the sin or cos table directly has other uses mentioned
045 * in its docs (in particular, uniform random unit vectors).
046 * <br>
047 * MathUtils had its sin and cos methods created by Riven on JavaGaming.org . The versions of sin and cos here,
048 * including the way the lookup table is calculated, have been updated several times by Tommy Ettinger. The asin(),
049 * acos(), and atan() methods all use Taylor series approximations from the 1955 research study "Approximations for
050 * Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation; though one might think such code would be obsolete over 60 years later, the
051 * approximations from that study seem to have higher accuracy and speed than most attempts in later decades, often
052 * those aimed at DSP usage. Even older is the basis for sinSmooth() and cosSmooth(); the versions here are updated to
053 * be more precise, but are closely related to a 7th-century sine approximation by Bhaskara I. The update was given in
054 * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">this Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>. From the same site,
055 * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer by Soonts</a> provided the tan()
056 * method used here. The atan2Finite() family of methods is based on the
057 * very fast structure given by commenter "imuli" on
058 * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">Nic Taylor's DSP article</a>, but uses the last atan()
059 * Taylor series approximation from the aforementioned 1955 research study. The "precise" methods are all drawn from
060 * <a href="https://github.com/jrouwe/JoltPhysics">Jolt Physics</a> and its Vector4 implementation, which is where that
061 * library's trigonometry code ends up calling. Jolt uses SIMD optimization for its trigonometry and other math code,
062 * which unfortunately has no cross-platform counterpart in Java at the time of writing (June 2025); the "precise"
063 * methods here are mostly ports of the C++ methods with the SIMD-specific code replaced with scalar code. Jolt was
064 * written by Jorrit Rouwe and is MIT-licensed; the code based on Jolt here was in turn based partly on code for the
065 * Cephes library by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
066 */
067@SuppressWarnings({"ExpressionComparedToItself", "PointlessArithmeticExpression"})
068public final class TrigTools {
069
070    /**
071     * Not meant to be instantiated.
072     */
073    private TrigTools() {
074    }
075//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Constants">
076
077    /**
078     * The {@code float} value that is closer than any other to
079     * <i>pi</i>, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its
080     * diameter.
081     */
082    public static final float PI = (float) Math.PI;
083    /**
084     * 1.0f divided by {@link #PI}.
085     */
086    public static final float PI_INVERSE = (float) (1.0 / Math.PI);
087    /**
088     * 2f times {@link #PI}; the same as {@link #TAU}.
089     */
090    public static final float PI2 = PI * 2f;
091    /**
092     * 2f times {@link #PI}; the same as {@link #PI2}.
093     */
094    public static final float TAU = PI2;
095    /**
096     * {@link #PI} divided by 2f; the same as {@link #ETA}.
097     */
098    public static final float HALF_PI = PI * 0.5f;
099    /**
100     * {@link #PI} divided by 2f; the same as {@link #HALF_PI}.
101     */
102    public static final float ETA = HALF_PI;
103    /**
104     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 2.0; the same as {@link #ETA_D}.
105     */
106    public static final double HALF_PI_D = Math.PI * 0.5;
107    /**
108     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 2.0; the same as {@link #HALF_PI_D}.
109     */
110    public static final double ETA_D = HALF_PI_D;
111    /**
112     * {@link #PI} divided by 4f.
113     */
114    public static final float QUARTER_PI = PI * 0.25f;
115
116    /**
117     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 4.0.
118     */
119    public static final double QUARTER_PI_D = Math.PI * 0.25;
120
121    /**
122     * The hard-coded size of {@link #SIN_TABLE} and {@link #COS_TABLE} in
123     * bits; this is 14 now, and could be adjusted in the future.
124     */
125    public static final int TABLE_BITS = 14; // 64KB. Adjust for accuracy.
126    /**
127     * The size of {@link #SIN_TABLE}, available separately from the table's length for convenience.
128     */
129    public static final int TABLE_SIZE = (1 << TABLE_BITS);
130
131    /**
132     * If you add this to an index used in {@link #SIN_TABLE}, you get the result of the cosine instead of the sine.
133     */
134    public static final int SIN_TO_COS = TABLE_SIZE >>> 2;
135
136    /**
137     * The change in angle required to go a quarter of the way around a circle, as measured in table indices for use
138     * with {@link #SIN_TABLE} and {@link #COS_TABLE}. Equivalent to {@link #SIN_TO_COS}.
139     */
140    public static final int QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX = SIN_TO_COS;
141
142    /**
143     * The bitmask that can be used to confine any int to wrap within {@link #TABLE_SIZE}. Any accesses to
144     * {@link #SIN_TABLE} with an index that could be out of bounds should probably be wrapped using this, as with
145     * {@code SIN_TABLE[index & TABLE_MASK]}.
146     */
147    public static final int TABLE_MASK = TABLE_SIZE - 1;
148
149    /**
150     * Multiply by this to convert from a float angle in radians to an index in {@link #SIN_TABLE} (after it is rounded to int and masked with {@link #TABLE_MASK}).
151     */
152    public static final float radToIndex = TABLE_SIZE / PI2;
153    /**
154     * Multiply by this to convert from a float angle in degrees to an index in {@link #SIN_TABLE} (after it is rounded to int and masked with {@link #TABLE_MASK}).
155     */
156    public static final float degToIndex = TABLE_SIZE / 360f;
157    /**
158     * Multiply by this to convert from a float angle in turns to an index in {@link #SIN_TABLE} (after it is rounded to int and masked with {@link #TABLE_MASK}).
159     */
160    public static final float turnToIndex = TABLE_SIZE;
161
162    /**
163     * Multiply by this to convert from radians to degrees.
164     */
165    public static final float radiansToDegrees = (float) (180.0 / Math.PI);
166    /**
167     * Multiply by this to convert from degrees to radians.
168     */
169    public static final float degreesToRadians = (float) (Math.PI / 180.0);
170
171    /**
172     * A precalculated table of 16385 floats, corresponding to the y-value of points on the unit circle, ordered by
173     * increasing angle. This should not be mutated, but it can be accessed directly for things like getting random
174     * unit vectors, or implementing the "sincos" method (which assigns sin() to one item and cos() to another).
175     * <br>
176     * A quick way to get a random unit vector is to get a random number that can be no larger than the table size, as
177     * with {@code int angle = (random.nextInt() & TrigTools.TABLE_MASK);}, and look up that angle in {@code COS_TABLE}
178     * for the vector's x and {@code SIN_TABLE} for the vector's y.
179     * Elements 0 and 16384 are identical to allow wrapping.
180     */
181    public static final float[] SIN_TABLE = new float[TABLE_SIZE+1];
182
183    /**
184     * A precalculated table of 16385 floats, corresponding to the x-value of points on the unit circle, ordered by
185     * increasing angle. This should not be mutated, but it can be accessed directly for things like getting random
186     * unit vectors, or implementing the "sincos" method (which assigns sin() to one item and cos() to another).
187     * <br>
188     * A quick way to get a random unit vector is to get a random number that can be no larger than the table size, as
189     * with {@code int angle = (random.nextInt() & TrigTools.TABLE_MASK);}, and look up that angle in {@code COS_TABLE}
190     * for the vector's x and {@code SIN_TABLE} for the vector's y.
191     * Elements 0 and 16384 are identical to allow wrapping.
192     */
193    public static final float[] COS_TABLE = new float[TABLE_SIZE+1];
194
195    static {
196        for (int i = 0; i <= TABLE_SIZE; i++) {
197            float theta = ((float)i) / TABLE_SIZE * PI2;
198            SIN_TABLE[i] = sinPrecise(theta);
199            COS_TABLE[i] = cosPrecise(theta);
200        }
201
202/*
203 // This section can be uncommented to check how precise the 90-degree-angle increments are.
204 // Surprisingly, the angles corresponding to 180 degrees (for sine) or 270 degrees (for cosine) are not exactly 0.
205        float[] debug;
206        double[] debugD;
207        debug = new float[]{
208        SIN_TABLE[0]                       ,
209        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX]    ,
210        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 2],
211        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 3],
212        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 4],
213        };
214        for(float f : debug) System.out.printf("%f %08X\n", f, NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(f));
215        debug = new float[]{
216        COS_TABLE[0]                       ,
217        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX]    ,
218        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 2],
219        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 3],
220        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 4],
221        };
222        for(float f : debug) System.out.printf("%f %08X\n", f, NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(f));
223*/
224        // The four right angles get extra-precise values, because they are
225        // the most likely to need to be correct.
226
227        SIN_TABLE[0]                          = 0f;
228        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX]       = 1f;
229        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 2]   = 0f;
230        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 3]   = -1.0f;
231        SIN_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 4]   = 0f;
232
233        COS_TABLE[0]                          = 1f;
234        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX]       = 0f;
235        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 2]   = -1f;
236        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 3]   = 0f;
237        COS_TABLE[QUARTER_CIRCLE_INDEX * 4]   = 1f;
238    }
239//</editor-fold>
240//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Table Queries">
241    /**
242     * Converts {@code radians} to an index that can be used in {@link #SIN_TABLE} or {@link #COS_TABLE}
243     * to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have
244     * one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere).
245     * This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
246     *
247     * @param radians an angle in radians; may be positive or negative
248     * @return the index into {@link #SIN_TABLE} of the sine of radians
249     */
250    public static int radiansToTableIndex(final float radians) {
251        return (int) (radians * radToIndex + 16384.5f) & TABLE_MASK;
252    }
253
254    /**
255     * Converts {@code degrees} to an index that can be used in {@link #SIN_TABLE} or {@link #COS_TABLE}
256     * to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have
257     * one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere).
258     * This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
259     *
260     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; may be positive or negative
261     * @return the index into {@link #SIN_TABLE} of the sine of degrees
262     */
263    public static int degreesToTableIndex(final float degrees) {
264        return (int)(degrees * degToIndex + 16384.5f) & TABLE_MASK;
265    }
266
267    /**
268     * Converts {@code turns} to an index that can be used in {@link #SIN_TABLE} or {@link #COS_TABLE}
269     * to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have
270     * one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere).
271     * This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
272     *
273     * @param turns an angle in turns; may be positive or negative
274     * @return the index into {@link #SIN_TABLE} of the sine of turns
275     */
276    public static int turnsToTableIndex(final float turns) {
277        return (int)(turns * turnToIndex + 16384.5f) & TABLE_MASK;
278    }
279//</editor-fold>
280//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Sine, Cosine, and Tangent">
281
282    /**
283     * Gets an approximation of the sine of {@code radians}. This offers about 2x to
284     * 4x the throughput of {@link Math#sin(double)} (cast to float).
285     * <br>
286     * Internally, this uses {@link #SIN_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
287     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
288     * @param radians an angle in radians; optimally between {@code -PI2} and {@code PI2}
289     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
290     */
291    public static float sin(float radians) {
292        radians *= radToIndex;
293        final int floor = (int)(radians + 16384f) - 16384;
294        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
295        final float from = SIN_TABLE[masked], to = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
296        return from + (to - from) * (radians - floor);
297    }
298
299    /**
300     * Gets an approximation of the cosine of {@code radians}. This offers about 2x to
301     * 4x the throughput of {@link Math#cos(double)} (cast to float).
302     * <br>
303     * Internally, this uses {@link #COS_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
304     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
305     * @param radians an angle in radians; optimally between {@code -PI2} and {@code PI2}
306     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
307     */
308    public static float cos(float radians) {
309        radians = Math.abs(radians) * radToIndex;
310        final int floor = (int)radians;
311        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
312        final float from = COS_TABLE[masked], to = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
313        return from + (to - from) * (radians - floor);
314    }
315
316    /**
317     * Gets an approximation of the tangent of {@code radians}. This offers much
318     * higher throughput than {@link Math#tan(double)} (cast to float).
319     * <br>
320     * Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by
321     * adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in {@link #SIN_TABLE} and
322     * {@link #COS_TABLE}, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the
323     * cosine.
324     * @param radians a float angle in radians, where 0 to {@link #PI2} is one rotation
325     * @return a float approximation of tan()
326     */
327    public static float tan(float radians) {
328        radians *= radToIndex;
329        final int floor = (int)(radians + 16384.0) - 16384;
330        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
331        radians -= floor;
332        final float fromS = SIN_TABLE[masked], toS = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
333        final float fromC = COS_TABLE[masked], toC = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
334        return (fromS + (toS - fromS) * radians) / (fromC + (toC - fromC) * radians);
335    }
336
337
338    /**
339     * Gets an approximation of the sine of {@code degrees}. This offers about 2x
340     * to 4x the throughput of {@link Math#sin(double)} (converted from degrees and cast to float).
341     * <br>
342     * Internally, this uses {@link #SIN_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
343     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
344     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; optimally between -360 and 360
345     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
346     */
347    public static float sinDeg(float degrees) {
348        degrees *= degToIndex;
349        final int floor = (int)(degrees + 16384f) - 16384;
350        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
351        final float from = SIN_TABLE[masked], to = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
352        return from + (to - from) * (degrees - floor);
353    }
354
355    /**
356     * Gets an approximation of the cosine of {@code degrees}. This offers about 2x to
357     * 4x the throughput of {@link Math#cos(double)} (converted from degrees and cast to float).
358     * <br>
359     * Internally, this uses {@link #COS_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
360     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
361     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; optimally between -360 and 360
362     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
363     */
364    public static float cosDeg(float degrees) {
365        degrees = Math.abs(degrees) * degToIndex;
366        final int floor = (int)degrees;
367        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
368        final float from = COS_TABLE[masked], to = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
369        return from + (to - from) * (degrees - floor);
370    }
371
372    /**
373     * Gets an approximation of the tangent of {@code degrees}. This offers much
374     * higher throughput than {@link Math#tan(double)} (converted from degrees and cast to float).
375     * <br>
376     * Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by
377     * adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in {@link #SIN_TABLE} and
378     * {@link #COS_TABLE}, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the
379     * cosine.
380     * @param degrees a float angle in degrees, where 0 to 360 is one rotation
381     * @return a float approximation of tan()
382     */
383    public static float tanDeg(float degrees) {
384        degrees *= degToIndex;
385        final int floor = (int)(degrees + 16384.0) - 16384;
386        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
387        degrees -= floor;
388        final float fromS = SIN_TABLE[masked], toS = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
389        final float fromC = COS_TABLE[masked], toC = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
390        return (fromS + (toS - fromS) * degrees) / (fromC + (toC - fromC) * degrees);
391    }
392
393    /**
394     * Gets an approximation of the sine of {@code turns}. This offers about 2x
395     * to 4x the throughput of {@link Math#sin(double)} (converted from turns and cast to float).
396     * <br>
397     * Internally, this uses {@link #SIN_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
398     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
399     * @param turns an angle in turns; optimally between -1 and 1
400     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
401     */
402    public static float sinTurns(float turns) {
403        turns *= turnToIndex;
404        final int floor = (int)(turns + 16384f) - 16384;
405        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
406        final float from = SIN_TABLE[masked], to = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
407        return from + (to - from) * (turns - floor);
408    }
409
410    /**
411     * Gets an approximation of the cosine of {@code turns}. This offers about 2x to
412     * 4x the throughput of {@link Math#cos(double)} (converted from turns and cast to float).
413     * <br>
414     * Internally, this uses {@link #COS_TABLE}, but interpolates between two
415     * adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
416     * @param turns an angle in turns; optimally between -1 and 1
417     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
418     */
419    public static float cosTurns(float turns) {
420        turns = Math.abs(turns) * turnToIndex;
421        final int floor = (int)turns;
422        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
423        final float from = COS_TABLE[masked], to = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
424        return from + (to - from) * (turns - floor);
425    }
426
427    /**
428     * Gets an approximation of the tangent of {@code turns}. This offers much
429     * higher throughput than {@link Math#tan(double)} (converted from turns and cast to float).
430     * <br>
431     * Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by
432     * adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in {@link #SIN_TABLE} and
433     * {@link #COS_TABLE}, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the
434     * cosine.
435     * @param turns a float angle in turns, where 0 to 1 is one rotation
436     * @return a float approximation of tan()
437     */
438    public static float tanTurns(float turns) {
439        turns *= turnToIndex;
440        final int floor = (int)(turns + 16384.0) - 16384;
441        final int masked = floor & TABLE_MASK;
442        turns -= floor;
443        final float fromS = SIN_TABLE[masked], toS = SIN_TABLE[masked+1];
444        final float fromC = COS_TABLE[masked], toC = COS_TABLE[masked+1];
445        return (fromS + (toS - fromS) * turns) / (fromC + (toC - fromC) * turns);
446    }
447//</editor-fold>
448//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Precise Sine, Cosine, and Tangent">
449
450    /**
451     * A non-tabular sine approximation in radians that is typically faster than {@link Math#sin(double)} and accurate
452     * to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to PI2 range. While this is slower than
453     * {@link TrigTools#sin(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
454     * significantly more accurate than sin().
455     * <br>
456     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
457     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
458     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
459     * @param radians input in radians, typically between -PI2 and PI2 for greatest precision
460     * @return the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
461     */
462    public static float sinPrecise(float radians) {
463        float x = Math.abs(radians);
464        int quadrant = (int)(0.6366197723675814f * x + 0.5f);
465        // Cody-Waite argument reduction, https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42455143/sine-cosine-modular-extended-precision-arithmetic
466        x = ((x - quadrant * 1.5703125f) - quadrant * 0.0004837512969970703125f) - quadrant * 7.549789948768648e-8f;
467        float x2 = x * x, s;
468        switch ((quadrant ^ (NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(radians) >>> 30 & 2)) & 3) {
469            case 0:
470                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
471                break;
472            case 1:
473                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
474                break;
475            case 2:
476                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
477                break;
478            default:
479                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
480        }
481        return s;
482    }
483
484    /**
485     * A non-tabular cosine approximation in radians that is typically faster than {@link Math#cos(double)} and
486     * accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to PI2 range. While this is slower than
487     * {@link TrigTools#cos(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
488     * significantly more accurate than cos().
489     * <br>
490     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
491     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
492     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
493     * @param radians input in radians, typically between -PI2 and PI2 for greatest precision
494     * @return the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
495     */
496    public static float cosPrecise(float radians) {
497        float x = Math.abs(radians);
498        int quadrant = (int)(0.6366197723675814f * x + 0.5f);
499        // Cody-Waite argument reduction, https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42455143/sine-cosine-modular-extended-precision-arithmetic
500        x = ((x - quadrant * 1.5703125f) - quadrant * 0.0004837512969970703125f) - quadrant * 7.549789948768648e-8f;
501        float x2 = x * x, s;
502        switch (quadrant & 3) {
503            case 3:
504                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
505                break;
506            case 0:
507                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
508                break;
509            case 1:
510                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
511                break;
512            default:
513                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
514        }
515        return s;
516    }
517
518    /**
519     * A non-tabular sine approximation in degrees that is typically faster than {@link Math#sin(double)} and accurate
520     * to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 360 range. While this is slower than
521     * {@link TrigTools#sinDeg(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
522     * significantly more accurate than sinDeg().
523     * <br>
524     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
525     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
526     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
527     * @param degrees input in degrees, typically between -360 and 360 for greatest precision
528     * @return the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
529     */
530    public static float sinDegPrecise(float degrees) {
531        float x = Math.abs(degrees);
532        int quadrant = (int)(0.011111111f * x + 0.5f);
533        x = (x - quadrant * 90f) * (HALF_PI / 90f);
534        float x2 = x * x, s;
535        switch ((quadrant ^ (NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(degrees) >>> 30 & 2)) & 3) {
536            case 0:
537                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
538                break;
539            case 1:
540                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
541                break;
542            case 2:
543                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
544                break;
545            default:
546                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
547        }
548        return s;
549    }
550
551    /**
552     * A non-tabular cosine approximation in degrees that is typically faster than {@link Math#cos(double)} and
553     * accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 360 range. While this is slower than
554     * {@link TrigTools#cosDeg(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
555     * significantly more accurate than cosDeg().
556     * <br>
557     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
558     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
559     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
560     * @param degrees input in degrees, typically between -360 and 360 for greatest precision
561     * @return the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
562     */
563    public static float cosDegPrecise(float degrees) {
564        float x = Math.abs(degrees);
565        int quadrant = (int)(0.011111111f * x + 0.5f);
566        x = (x - quadrant * 90f) * (HALF_PI / 90f);
567        float x2 = x * x, s;
568        switch (quadrant & 3) {
569            case 3:
570                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
571                break;
572            case 0:
573                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
574                break;
575            case 1:
576                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
577                break;
578            default:
579                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
580        }
581        return s;
582    }

584    /**
585     * A non-tabular sine approximation in turns that is typically faster than {@link Math#sin(double)} and accurate
586     * to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 1 range. While this is slower than
587     * {@link TrigTools#sinTurns(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
588     * significantly more accurate than sinTurns().
589     * <br>
590     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
591     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
592     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
593     * @param turns input in turns, typically between -1 and 1 for greatest precision
594     * @return the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
595     */
596    public static float sinTurnsPrecise(float turns) {
597        float x = Math.abs(turns);
598        int quadrant = (int)(4f * x + 0.5f);
599        x = (x - quadrant * 0.25f) * PI2;
600        float x2 = x * x, s;
601        switch ((quadrant ^ (NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(turns) >>> 30 & 2)) & 3) {
602            case 0:
603                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
604                break;
605            case 1:
606                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
607                break;
608            case 2:
609                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
610                break;
611            default:
612                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
613        }
614        return s;
615    }

617    /**
618     * A non-tabular cosine approximation in turns that is typically faster than {@link Math#cos(double)} and
619     * accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 1 range. While this is slower than
620     * {@link TrigTools#cosTurns(float)}, it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are
621     * significantly more accurate than cosTurns().
622     * <br>
623     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
624     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
625     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
626     * @param turns input in turns, typically between -1 and 1 for greatest precision
627     * @return the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive
628     */
629    public static float cosTurnsPrecise(float turns) {
630        float x = Math.abs(turns);
631        int quadrant = (int)(4f * x + 0.5f);
632        x = (x - quadrant * 0.25f) * PI2;
633        float x2 = x * x, s;
634        switch (quadrant & 3) {
635            case 3:
636                s = ((-1.9515295891e-4f * x2 + 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 - 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x + x;
637                break;
638            case 0:
639                s = ((2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 - (1.388731625493765e-3f)) * x2 + (4.166664568298827e-2f)) * x2 * x2 - 0.5f * x2 + 1f;
640                break;
641            case 1:
642                s = (((1.9515295891e-4f * x2 - 8.3321608736e-3f) * x2 + 1.6666654611e-1f) * x2 * x - x);
643                break;
644            default:
645                s = (((-2.443315711809948e-5f * x2 + 1.388731625493765e-3f) * x2 - 4.166664568298827e-2f) * x2 * x2 + 0.5f * x2 - 1f);
646        }
647        return s;
648    }
649
650    /**
651     * Returns the tangent in radians; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as
652     * {@link TrigTools#tan(float)}. This method is only very slightly more precise than tan();
653     * the difference is only about 2 ULPs for the worst-case absolute error in the -1 to 1 range, though the error
654     * almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd multiples of {@link TrigTools#HALF_PI}.
655     * The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the {@link TrigTools#SIN_TABLE} and
656     * {@link TrigTools#COS_TABLE} arrays are not in processor cache, this non-tabular method may become faster.
657     * <br>
658     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
659     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
660     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
661     *
662     * @param radians a float angle in radians, where 0 to {@link TrigTools#PI2} is one rotation
663     * @return a float approximation of tan()
664     */
665    public static float tanPrecise(float radians) {
666        float x = Math.abs(radians);
667        int quadrant = (int)(0.6366197723675814f * x + 0.5f);
668        // Cody-Waite argument reduction, https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42455143/sine-cosine-modular-extended-precision-arithmetic
669        x = ((x - quadrant * 1.5703125f) - quadrant * 0.0004837512969970703125f) - quadrant * 7.549789948768648e-8f;
670        float x2 = x * x;
671        float p = (((((9.38540185543e-3f * x2 + (3.11992232697e-3f)) * x2 + (2.44301354525e-2f)) * x2
672                + (5.34112807005e-2f)) * x2 + (1.33387994085e-1f)) * x2 + (3.33331568548e-1f)) * x2 * x + x;
673        if((quadrant & 1) == 1)
674            return -Math.signum(radians) / p;
675        return Math.signum(radians) * p;
676    }
677
678    /**
679     * Returns the tangent in degrees; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as
680     * {@link TrigTools#tanDeg(float)}. This method is only very slightly more precise than tanDeg(),
681     * though the error almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd multiples of 90.
682     * The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the {@link TrigTools#SIN_TABLE} and
683     * {@link TrigTools#COS_TABLE} arrays are not in processor cache, this non-tabular method may become faster.
684     * <br>
685     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
686     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
687     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
688     *
689     * @param degrees a float angle in degrees, where 0 to {@code 360} is one rotation
690     * @return a float approximation of tan()
691     */
692    public static float tanDegPrecise(float degrees) {
693        float x = Math.abs(degrees);
694        int quadrant = (int)(0.011111111f * x + 0.5f);
695        x = (x - quadrant * 90f) * (HALF_PI / 90f);
696        float x2 = x * x;
697        float p = (((((9.38540185543e-3f * x2 + (3.11992232697e-3f)) * x2 + (2.44301354525e-2f)) * x2
698                + (5.34112807005e-2f)) * x2 + (1.33387994085e-1f)) * x2 + (3.33331568548e-1f)) * x2 * x + x;
699        if((quadrant & 1) == 1)
700            return -Math.signum(degrees) / p;
701        return Math.signum(degrees) * p;
702    }
703
704    /**
705     * Returns the tangent in turns; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as
706     * {@link TrigTools#tanTurns(float)}. This method is only very slightly more precise than
707     * tanTurns(), though the error almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd
708     * multiples of 0.25. The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the
709     * {@link TrigTools#SIN_TABLE} and {@link TrigTools#COS_TABLE} arrays are not in processor cache, this
710     * non-tabular method may become faster.
711     * <br>
712     * Based on <a href="https://jrouwe.github.io/JoltPhysics/_vec4_8inl_source.html">Jolt's trigonometry code</a>.
713     * Jolt used an original implementation by <a href="https://www.moshier.net/">Stephen L. Moshier</a>.
714     * Jolt is MIT-licensed.
715     *
716     * @param turns a float angle in turns, where 0.0 to 1.0 is one rotation
717     * @return a float approximation of tan()
718     */
719    public static float tanTurnsPrecise(float turns) {
720        float x = Math.abs(turns);
721        int quadrant = (int)(4 * x + 0.5f);
722        x = (x - quadrant * 0.25f) * PI2;
723        float x2 = x * x;
724        float p = (((((9.38540185543e-3f * x2 + (3.11992232697e-3f)) * x2 + (2.44301354525e-2f)) * x2
725                + (5.34112807005e-2f)) * x2 + (1.33387994085e-1f)) * x2 + (3.33331568548e-1f)) * x2 * x + x;
726        if((quadrant & 1) == 1)
727            return -Math.signum(turns) / p;
728        return Math.signum(turns) * p;
729    }

733
734    /**
735     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
736     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise). This
737     * method is usually about 4x faster than {@link Math#atan(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
738     *
739     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
740     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from {@code -HALF_PI} to {@code HALF_PI} inclusive
741     */
742    public static float atan(float i) {
743        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
744        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
745        // again when converted back to float.
746        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
747        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
748        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
749        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
750        double c2 = c * c;
751        double c3 = c * c2;
752        double c5 = c3 * c2;
753        double c7 = c5 * c2;
754        double c9 = c7 * c2;
755        double c11 = c9 * c2;
756        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (QUARTER_PI_D
757                + (0.99997726 * c - 0.33262347 * c3 + 0.19354346 * c5 - 0.11643287 * c7 + 0.05265332 * c9 - 0.0117212 * c11)));
758    }
759
760    /**
761     * Arc tangent approximation returning a value measured in positive or negative degrees, using an algorithm from the
762     * 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm,
763     * which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
764     *
765     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
766     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from {@code -90} to {@code 90} inclusive
767     */
768    public static float atanDeg(float i) {
769        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
770        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
771        // again when converted back to float.
772        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
773        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
774        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
775        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
776        double c2 = c * c;
777        double c3 = c * c2;
778        double c5 = c3 * c2;
779        double c7 = c5 * c2;
780        double c9 = c7 * c2;
781        double c11 = c9 * c2;
782        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (45.0
783                + (57.2944766070562 * c - 19.05792099799635 * c3 + 11.089223410359068 * c5 - 6.6711120475953765 * c7 + 3.016813013351768 * c9 - 0.6715752908287405 * c11)));
784    }
785
786    /**
787     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
788     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
789     *
790     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
791     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from {@code -0.25} to {@code 0.25} inclusive
792     */
793    public static float atanTurns(float i) {
794        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
795        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
796        // again when converted back to float.
797        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
798        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
799        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
800        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
801        double c2 = c * c;
802        double c3 = c * c2;
803        double c5 = c3 * c2;
804        double c7 = c5 * c2;
805        double c9 = c7 * c2;
806        double c11 = c9 * c2;
807        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (0.125
808                + (0.15915132390848943 * c - 0.052938669438878753 * c3 + 0.030803398362108523 * c5
809                - 0.01853086679887605 * c7 + 0.008380036148199356 * c9 - 0.0018654869189687236 * c11)));
810    }

813    /**
814     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
815     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise). This
816     * method is usually about 4x faster than {@link Math#atan(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
817     *
818     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
819     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from {@code -HALF_PI} to {@code HALF_PI} inclusive
820     */
821    public static double atan(double i) {
822        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
823        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
824        // again when converted back to double.
825        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
826        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
827        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
828        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
829        double c2 = c * c;
830        double c3 = c * c2;
831        double c5 = c3 * c2;
832        double c7 = c5 * c2;
833        double c9 = c7 * c2;
834        double c11 = c9 * c2;
835        return Math.signum(i) * (QUARTER_PI_D
836                + (0.99997726 * c - 0.33262347 * c3 + 0.19354346 * c5 - 0.11643287 * c7 + 0.05265332 * c9 - 0.0117212 * c11));
837    }

845     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from {@code -90} to {@code 90} inclusive
846     */
847    public static double atanDeg(double i) {
848        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
849        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
850        // again when converted back to double.
851        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
852        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
853        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
854        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.

858        double c7 = c5 * c2;
859        double c9 = c7 * c2;

865    /**
866     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
867     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
868     *
869     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
870     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from {@code -0.25} to {@code 0.25} inclusive
871     */
872    public static double atanTurns(double i) {
873        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
874        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
875        // again when converted back to double.
876        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
877        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
878        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
879        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
880        double c2 = c * c;
881        double c3 = c * c2;
882        double c5 = c3 * c2;
883        double c7 = c5 * c2;
884        double c9 = c7 * c2;
885        double c11 = c9 * c2;
886        return Math.signum(i) * (0.125
887                + (0.15915132390848943 * c - 0.052938669438878753 * c3 + 0.030803398362108523 * c5
888                - 0.01853086679887605 * c7 + 0.008380036148199356 * c9 - 0.0018654869189687236 * c11));
889    }
890//</editor-fold>
891//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Atan2">
892    /**
893     * A fast approximation of {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} that is only defined for finite input arguments.
894     * The atan2() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in radians from
895     * the origin to the given point. If y is non-negative, this returns a float from 0.0
896     * to {@link #PI}, otherwise it returns a float from -0.0 to -PI.
897     * <br>
898     * This returns NaN when given
899     * infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where {@code y == 0f && x == 0f},
900     * this returns y (which may be -0.0); this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns
901     * {@link Math#PI} when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
902     * <br>
903     * Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on
904     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">Taylor's article</a> with very useful info.
905     * Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955)
906     * for its atan() approximation over the {@code (0,1]} domain.
907     *
908     * @param y any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
909     * @param x any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
910     * @return the angle in radians from the origin to the given point
911     */
912    public static float atan2(final float y, final float x) {
913        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return y;
914        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
915        boolean invert = ay > ax;
916        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
917        float s = z * z;
918        z *= (((((((-0.004054058f * s + 0.0218612288f) * s - 0.0559098861f) * s + 0.0964200441f)
919                * s - 0.1390853351f) * s + 0.1994653599f) * s - 0.3332985605f) * s + 0.9999993329f);
920        if (invert) z = HALF_PI - z;
921        if (x < 0f) z = PI - z;
922        return y < 0f ? -z : z;
923    }
924
925    /**
926     * A fast approximation of atan2() in degrees that is only defined for finite input arguments.
927     * The atan2Deg() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in degrees from
928     * the origin to the given point. If y is non-negative, this returns a float from 0.0
929     * to 180.0 , otherwise it returns a float from -0.0 to -180.0 .
930     * <br>
931     * This returns NaN when given
932     * infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where {@code y == 0f && x == 0f},
933     * this returns y (which may be -0.0); this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns
934     * {@link Math#PI} (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
935     * <br>
936     * Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on
937     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">Taylor's article</a> with very useful info.
938     * Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955)
939     * for its atan() approximation over the {@code (0,1]} domain.
940     *
941     * @param y any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
942     * @param x any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
943     * @return the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point
944     */
945    public static float atan2Deg(final float y, final float x) {
946        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return y;
947        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
948        boolean invert = ay > ax;
949        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
950        float s = z * z;
951        z *= ((((((-0.2322804062831325f * s + 1.2525561619334924f) * s - 3.2034005556446465f) * s + 5.52446147949459f)
952                * s - 7.969002832028255f) * s + 11.428523528717331f) * s - 19.09660103251952f) * s + 57.29574194704188f;
953        if (invert) z = 90f - z;
954        if (x < 0f) z = 180f - z;
955        return y < 0f ? -z : z;
956    }
957
958    /**
959     * A fast approximation of atan2() in non-negative degrees that is only defined for finite input arguments.
960     * The atan2Deg360() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in degrees from
961     * the origin to the given point. This returns a float from 0.0 to 360.0, counterclockwise
962     * when y points up.
963     * <br>
964     * This returns NaN when given
965     * infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where {@code y == 0f && x == 0f},
966     * this returns 0.0; this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns
967     * {@link Math#PI} (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
968     * <br>
969     * Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on
970     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">Taylor's article</a> with very useful info.
971     * Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955)
972     * for its atan() approximation over the {@code (0,1]} domain.
973     *
974     * @param y any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
975     * @param x any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
976     * @return the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point, from 0 to 360
977     */
978    public static float atan2Deg360(final float y, final float x) {
979        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
980        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
981        boolean invert = ay > ax;
982        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
983        float s = z * z;
984        z *= ((((((-0.2322804062831325f * s + 1.2525561619334924f) * s - 3.2034005556446465f) * s + 5.52446147949459f) * s - 7.969002832028255f)
985                * s + 11.428523528717331f) * s - 19.09660103251952f) * s + 57.29574194704188f;
986        if (invert) z = 90f - z;
987        if (x < 0f) z = 180f - z;
988        return y < 0f ? 360f - z : z;
989    }
990
991    /**
992     * A fast approximation of atan2() in turns that is only defined for finite input arguments.
993     * The atan2Turns() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in turns from
994     * the origin to the given point. This returns a float from 0.0 to 1.0, counterclockwise
995     * when y points up.
996     * <br>
997     * This returns NaN when given
998     * infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where {@code y == 0f && x == 0f},
999     * this returns 0.0; this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns
1000     * {@link Math#PI} (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
1001     * <br>
1002     * Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on
1003     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">Taylor's article</a> with very useful info.
1004     * Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955)
1005     * for its atan() approximation over the {@code (0,1]} domain.
1006     *
1007     * @param y any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
1008     * @param x any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
1009     * @return the angle in turns from the origin to the given point, from 0.0 to 1.0
1010     */
1011    public static float atan2Turns(final float y, final float x) {
1012        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1013        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1014        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1015        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1016        float s = z * z;
1017        z *= (((((((-6.452233507864792E-4f * s + 0.003479322672037479f) * s - 0.008898334876790684f) * s + 0.015345726331929417f) * s - 0.022136118977856264f)
1018                * s + 0.03174589869088148f) * s - 0.05304611397922089f) * s + 0.15915483874178302f);
1019        if (invert) z = 0.25f - z;
1020        if (x < 0f) z = 0.5f - z;
1021        return y < 0f ? 1f - z : z;
1022    }
1023//</editor-fold>
1024//<editor-fold defaultstate="collapsed" desc="Arcsine and Arccosine">
1025
1026    /**
1027     * Returns arcsine in radians; less accurate than Math.asin but may be faster. Average error of 0.000028447 radians (0.0016298931
1028     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067592 radians (0.0038727364 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1029     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1030     *
1031     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1032     * @return between {@code -HALF_PI} and {@code HALF_PI} when a is in the defined range
1033     */
1034    public static float asin(final float a) {
1035        if (a >= 0f) {
1036            return (float) (HALF_PI_D - Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (1.5707288 + a * (-0.2121144 + a * (0.0742610 + a * -0.0187293))));
1037        }
1038        return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (1.5707288 + a * (0.2121144 + a * (0.0742610 + a * 0.0187293))) - HALF_PI_D);
1039    }
1040
1041    /**
1042     * Returns arcsine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1043     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1044     *
1045     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1046     * @return between {@code -90} and {@code 90} when a is in the defined range
1047     */
1048    public static float asinDeg(float a) {
1049        if (a >= 0f) {
1050            return (float) (90.0 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (89.99613099964837 + a * (-12.153259893949748 + a * (4.2548418824210055 + a * -1.0731098432343729))));
1051        }
1052        return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (89.99613099964837 + a * (12.153259893949748 + a * (4.2548418824210055 + a * 1.0731098432343729))) - 90.0);
1053    }
1054
1055    /**
1056     * Returns arcsine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1057     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1058     * Note that unlike {@link #atan2Turns(float, float)}, this can return negative turn values.
1059     *
1060     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1061     * @return between {@code -0.25} and {@code 0.25} when a is in the defined range
1062     */
1063    public static float asinTurns(float a) {
1064        if (a >= 0f) {
1065            return (float) (0.25 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (0.24998925277680104 + a * (-0.033759055260971525 + a * (0.011819005228947238 + a * -0.0029808606756510357))));
1066        }
1067        return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (0.24998925277680104 + a * (0.033759055260971525 + a * (0.011819005228947238 + a * 0.0029808606756510357))) - 0.25);
1068    }
1069
1070    /**
1071     * Returns arccosine in radians; less accurate than Math.acos but may be faster. Average error of 0.00002845 radians (0.0016300649
1072     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067548 radians (0.0038702153 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1073     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1074     *
1075     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1076     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code PI} when a is in the defined range
1077     */
1078    public static float acos(float a) {
1079        if (a >= 0f) {
1080            return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (1.5707288 + a * (-0.2121144 + a * (0.0742610 + a * -0.0187293))));
1081        }
1082        return (float) (Math.PI
1083                - Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (1.5707288 + a * (0.2121144 + a * (0.0742610 + a * 0.0187293))));
1084    }
1085
1086    /**
1087     * Returns arccosine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1088     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1089     *
1090     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1091     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code 180} when a is in the defined range
1092     */
1093    public static float acosDeg(float a) {
1094        if (a >= 0f) {
1095            return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (89.99613099964837 + a * (-12.153259533621753 + a * (4.254842010910525 + a * -1.0731098035209208))));
1096        }
1097        return (float) (180.0
1098                - Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (89.99613099964837 + a * (12.153259533621753 + a * (4.254842010910525 + a * 1.0731098035209208))));
1099    }
1100
1101    /**
1102     * Returns arccosine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1103     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1104     *
1105     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
1106     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code 0.5} when a is in the defined range
1107     */
1108    public static float acosTurns(float a) {
1109        if (a >= 0f) {
1110            return (float)(Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (0.24998925277680104 + a * (-0.033759055260971525 + a * (0.011819005228947238 + a * -0.0029808606756510357))));
1111        }
1112        return (float)(0.5 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (0.24998925277680104 + a * (0.033759055260971525 + a * (0.011819005228947238 + a * 0.0029808606756510357))));
1113    }
1114//</editor-fold>
